summary: This document is a chain of emails between Assistant U.S. Attorneys from the Southern District of New York and UK attorney Jill Greenfield regarding arranging an interview with Greenfield's client, a potential victim/witness in the Jeffrey Epstein investigation. The correspondence details logistical planning, assurances about the voluntary and sensitive nature of the interview, and mentions the client's complaint to the Met police about a sexual assault by Epstein while in London and employed by Ghislaine Maxwell.

persons.name: Jill Greenfield
persons.role: Partner at Fieldfisher law firm, attorney for a potential witness
persons.context: UK attorney representing a client who is a potential victim/witness in the SDNY Epstein investigation. She is negotiating the terms and logistics for her client to speak with U.S. prosecutors.

persons.name: Louise Scott
persons.context: Executive assistant at the Fieldfisher law firm, copied on email correspondence to help schedule calls and meetings.

persons.name: Kyle Phillips
persons.context: A colleague at Fieldfisher law firm, copied on some of the email correspondence regarding the Epstein investigation.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the SDNY investigation. The emails reference a client's complaint to the Met police regarding a sexual assault by Epstein.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Referred to as 'G Maxwell'. The client is described as having been in her employment in London at the time of the alleged assault by Epstein.

connections.description: Greenfield is the legal representative for a client who is a potential witness/victim in the Epstein case.
The client made a complaint to the Met police regarding a sexual assault by Jeffrey Epstein.
The client was allegedly in the employment of Ghislaine Maxwell in London at the time of the alleged assault.
Email correspondence negotiating the terms for a witness interview between Greenfield's client and the SDNY prosecution team.
Executive assistant and partner at the same law firm, coordinating schedules.

events.title: Initial Interview Proposal
events.description: SDNY prosecutors send a detailed email to Jill Greenfield outlining their sensitive approach to interviewing her client, a potential victim in the Epstein case.

events.title: Client's Conditions for Meeting
events.description: Greenfield relays her client's conditions for a meeting, including a two-part introductory/substantive session and the presence of a US lawyer friend.

events.title: Attorney Proffer Request Denied
events.description: Prosecutors request a general summary from Greenfield about her client's expected testimony (an attorney proffer). Greenfield declines, stating her client has made a complaint to the Met police about an assault by Epstein while employed by Maxwell.

events.title: Travel Plans Disrupted by Pandemic
events.description: Prosecutors inform Greenfield that international travel is shut down due to the COVID-19 pandemic, delaying plans for an in-person meeting in the UK.

events.title: Call Scheduling
events.description: Final emails in the chain coordinate a call for July 9, 2020, between the prosecutors and Jill Greenfield to discuss proceeding with the investigation during the pandemic.

locations: One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007
Fieldfisher, Riverbank House, 2 Swan Lane, London EC4R 3TT
keyFacts: A client of UK attorney Jill Greenfield made a formal complaint to the London Metropolitan Police (Met) regarding a sexual assault by Jeffrey Epstein that allegedly occurred while she was in London and employed by Ghislaine Maxwell.
The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York was actively seeking to interview this individual as a potential victim-witness in their Epstein investigation as of early 2020.
The correspondence reveals the SDNY prosecutors' standard protocol for interviewing victim-witnesses, emphasizing voluntariness, sensitivity, and allowing witnesses to control the topics discussed.
Logistical planning for an in-person interview in London was significantly disrupted by the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic in March 2020, leading to a pivot towards remote discussions.
The prosecutors reference their experience from the Weinstein investigation as a cautionary example of problems they sought to avoid in the Epstein case.
